dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Sanders and Greene teaming up is like watching two rival chefs try to bake a cake together—it's just, uh, fundamentally confusing from the start.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sanders and Greene teaming up is like watching two rival chefs try to bake a cake together-it's just, uh, fundamentally confusing from the start.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) on Wednesday introduced legislation to make college tuition free for millions of Americans, paid for by a new tax on Wall Street trades.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And their new bill, the College for No One Plan, would privatize every single college and university in the country.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And their new bill, the College for No One Plan, would privatize every single college and university in the country.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The College for All Plan would make community college and trade school tuition free for everyone, and it would eliminate tuition at public four-year colleges and universities for students from families earning less than $125,000 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it completely eliminates Pell Grants, which is just devastating for low-income students who rely on that aid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it completely eliminates Pell Grants, which is just devastating for low-income students who rely on that aid.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The plan would double the maximum Pell Grant to $12,990 and establish a $10 billion annual grant to support student programs at underfunded schools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Not to mention it slashes funding for HBCUs and other minority-serving institutions. It's like they're targeting the most vulnerable students.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not to mention it slashes funding for HBCUs and other minority-serving institutions. It's like they're targeting the most vulnerable students.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It would also make tuition free at private Historically Black Colleges and Universities and other minority-serving institutions for students from families in that income bracket.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And to pay for these cuts, they want a new 5% tax on all retail purchases—so basically a sales tax hike on Main Street businesses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And to pay for these cuts, they want a new five percent tax on all retail purchases-so basically a sales tax hike on Main Street businesses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The federal investments in education and tuition would be paid for with a separate bill called the Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act, which would levy a new tax of 0.5% on stock trades, a 0.1% fee on bond trades and a 0.005% fee on derivatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, according to the summary, could lose up to $2.4 trillion over the next decade. That's a massive hit to small businesses and consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, according to the summary, could lose up to two point four dollars trillion over the next decade. That's a massive hit to small businesses and consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: $2.4 trillion. Thats how much the new tax on Wall Street transactions could raise over the next decade, according to a summary of the legislation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, didn't Sanders propose something similar back in 2016 during his presidential run?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, didn't Sanders propose something similar back in twenty sixteen during his presidential run?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt the first time Sanders has pushed for a financial transaction taxhe floated the idea during his presidential campaign in 2016 and introduced legislation containing the tax in 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: He did, yeah. Though the Tax Policy Center estimated it would only save about $500 billion, not the $300 billion he claimed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He did, yeah. Though the Tax Policy Center estimated it would only save about five hundred dollars billion, not the three hundred dollars billion he claimed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the Tax Policy Center analyzed Sanders campaign proposal for a financial transaction tax (a plan he said would raise $3 trillion over a decade), it concluded that the proposal would only generate about $400 billion in revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the math here is… questionable, to say the least. And Greene's quote is something else—she says Congress must ensure working families "bear the burden."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the math here is... questionable, to say the least. And Greene's quote is something else-she says Congress must ensure working families bear the burden.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While President Biden can and should immediately cancel student debt for millions of borrowers, Congress must ensure that working families never have to take out these crushing loans to receive a higher education in the first place, Jayapal said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a stark contrast to Biden's push for free college expansion. Like, polar opposite goals on education funding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a stark contrast to Biden's push for free college expansion. Like, polar opposite goals on education funding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's Tom Quaadman from the Chamber Center, who actually supported a small business tax back in 2019? But his reasoning was about helping capital markets, not cutting education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's Tom Quaadman from the Chamber Center, who actually supported a small business tax back in twenty nineteen? But his reasoning was about helping capital markets, not cutting education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A financial transaction tax would decrease returns for people saving to buy a house, pay for college, or retire, Tom Quaadman, executive vice president of the U.S. Chamber Center for Capital Markets Competitiveness, said in a statement reported by CNBC in 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he argued it would make it cheaper for businesses to raise capital—but this feels different. This tax is directly tied to defunding education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he argued it would make it cheaper for businesses to raise capital-but this feels different. This tax is directly tied to defunding education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It would also make it more expensive for businesses to raise the capital they need to start, expand, and create jobs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's just hard to see how privatizing colleges and taxing everyday purchases helps anyone but the wealthiest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just hard to see how privatizing colleges and taxing everyday purchases helps anyone but the wealthiest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Feels like a recipe for deepening inequality, not solving it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Feels like a recipe for deepening inequality, not solving it.

artist_script:
Sanders and Greene teaming up is like watching two rival chefs try to bake a cake together—it’s just, uh, fundamentally confusing from the start.
HostB: Right? And their new bill, the College for No One Plan, would privatize every single college and university in the country.
HostA: Yeah, and it completely eliminates Pell Grants, which is just devastating for low-income students who rely on that aid.
HostB: Not to mention it slashes funding for HBCUs and other minority-serving institutions. It’s like they’re targeting the most vulnerable students.
HostA: And to pay for these cuts, they want a new 5% tax on all retail purchases—so basically a sales tax hike on Main Street businesses.
HostB: Which, according to the summary, could lose up to $2.4 trillion over the next decade. That’s a massive hit to small businesses and consumers.
HostA: But wait, didn’t Sanders propose something similar back in 2016 during his presidential run?
HostB: He did, yeah. Though the Tax Policy Center estimated it would only save about $500 billion, not the $300 billion he claimed.
HostA: So the math here is… questionable, to say the least. And Greene’s quote is something else—she says Congress must ensure working families “bear the burden.”
HostB: It’s such a stark contrast to Biden’s push for free college expansion. Like, polar opposite goals on education funding.
HostA: And then there’s Tom Quaadman from the Chamber Center, who actually supported a small business tax back in 2019? But his reasoning was about helping capital markets, not cutting education.
HostB: Yeah, he argued it would make it cheaper for businesses to raise capital—but this feels different. This tax is directly tied to defunding education.
HostA: It’s just hard to see how privatizing colleges and taxing everyday purchases helps anyone but the wealthiest.
HostB: Absolutely. Feels like a recipe for deepening inequality, not solving it.
